facts.text: Appeals are Civil Appeals Nos. 1048 and 1050 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Civil, Appeals Nos. 10481050 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeals from judgment dated September 1958 of Bombay High Court in special Civil Applications Nos 1100, 1161 and 1162 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and debreedated September 1958 of the Bombay High Court iii special Civil Applications Nos 1100, 1161 and 1162 of 1958.

facts.text: Appellants held shares in the inam village of Wanz and some in that of Dindoli.

anchor.surface_text: Some of the appellants held shares in the inam village of Wanz and some in that of Dindoli.

facts.text: Appellants moved High Court by petitions under Arts. 226 and 227 for quashing decision of Bombay Revenue Tribunal regarding compensation.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants had moved the High Court at Bombay by several petitions under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution for quashing the decision of the Bombay Revenue Tribunal regarding the companypensation.

facts.text: High Court disposed of petitions by common judgment; appeals under certificate granted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The petitions were disposed of by the High Court by a companymon judgment. These appeals are against that judgment under a certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Two surviving claims: entitlement to compensation for loss of assessment payable by inferior holders of tenants.

anchor.surface_text: The first is that the appellants are entitled to companypensation for loss of assessment payable to them by inferior holders, a special class, of tenants holding lands from them.

facts.text: Bombay Personal Inams Abolition Act, 1952 abolished inams.

anchor.surface_text: These three appeals companycern companypensation payable under the Bombay Personal Inams Abolition Act, 1952 to the appellants for abolition of their inams.

facts.text: Grants made in 1794 and 1803 respectively.

anchor.surface_text: grants which were made in 1794 and 1803 respectively

facts.text: Survey introduced in the villages in 1900 under the Bombay Land Revenue Code, 1879.

anchor.surface_text: after the introduction of the survey in the villages in 1900 under the Bombay Land Revenue Code, 1879

facts.text: High Court held on construction of sanads that inams were grants of villages with exemption from land revenue.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held on a companystruction of the sanads that the inams were grants of the villages with exemption from land revenue, because the words of the grant companyveyed the soil and rights over trees, water, mines etc.

facts.text: Appellants contended inams consisted of grant of land revenue only.

anchor.surface_text: According to them, their inams companysisted of a grant of land re. venue only.

facts.text: After grants, what tenants paid to inamdars was rent not revenue.

anchor.surface_text: What the tenants paid to the inamdars  holders of the inams  after the grants was rent and number revenue

facts.text: Survey fixed amount payable by tenant to inamdar but did not alter nature to land revenue.

anchor.surface_text: No Doubt since the introduction of the survey the amounts payable by the tenants to the inamdars were all assessed under the Code. The nature of the assessment payable was number however altered thereby number did it become land revenue.

facts.text: In both villages there were inferior holders claiming through tillers in possession at time of grant.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that in both the villages there were holders of land called inferior holders. These were persons claiming through tillers in cultivating possession of different pieces of land in the Inam villages at the time of the grant of the Inams.

facts.text: Under S. 216 of Bombay Land Revenue Code, 1879 settlement introduced in both villages.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that under S. 216 of the Bombay Land Revenue Code, 1879 settlement was introduced both in Wanz and Dindoli villages though at different points of time.

facts.text: After survey, inferior holders liable to pay land revenue assessed at settlement to Inamdar.

anchor.surface_text: It is also the companymon case of the parties that after the introduction of the survey, land revenue was assessed on the lands held by the inferior holders and in place of their liability to pay such rent as may be fixed from time to time by the Inamdars they thenceforward were rendered liable to pay to the Inamdar only the land revenue assessed at the settlement.

facts.text: No liability cast on Inamdars to pay land revenue in respect of lands in possession of inferior holders per s.5 of Act.

anchor.surface_text: No liability is, however, cast upon them to pay to the Government land revenue in respect of lands in the possession of inferior holders. This follows clearly from s. 5 of the Act and is number disputed by either set of parties to the appeal.

facts.text: Appellants failed to produce evidence for claim under right to forfeit tenancies and right of reversion.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector asked the appellants to produce evidence in support of their claims under this head. They failed to do so. They companyld number even cite one instance of the exercise of any such right.

facts.text: Collector of Surat and Bombay Revenue Tribunal held first claim barred by s.17(5), second not proved.

anchor.surface_text: The Collect-or of surat and the Bombay Revenue Tribunal companycurrently held that the claim for companypensation, in respect of the first item was barred by s. 17 5  of the Act and in respect of the claim under the second head, the appellants failed to prove that they sustained any loss.

facts.text: High Court dismissed applications under Arts. 226 and 227 challenging findings.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed applications under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution before the High Court at Bombay challenging the Correctness of these findings. The High Court dismissed the applications.

facts.text: Inams were grants of villages partially exempt from land revenue, first category under s.2(1)(e)(i).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held-and, in my opinion, rightly that the grants of the villages, on their true companystruction were grants of the soil. The inamdars were number required to pay any land revenue except the quit rent and some small haqs.

facts.text: Survey and settlement under s.216 did not change character of inams or status of inferior holders.

anchor.surface_text: The survey and settlement of the villages under s. 216 of the Land- Revenue Code, 1879 made numberifference in the character of the inams. The introduction of the survey settlement did number companyfer on the inferior holders the status, of occupants,

facts.text: Appellants filed claims for compensation under ss.10 and 17(1) before Collector of Surat.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed claims for companypensation under ss. 10 and 17  1  of the Act before the Collector of Surat.

facts.text: Loss of right to recover assessment from inferior holders is nil as they would have had to pay it to Government.

facts.text: Appellants could not establish exercise of right of forfeiture or reversion.

holdings.text: The inams were grants of the villages with exemption from land revenue, being personal inams of the first category under s.2(1)(e)(i).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held on a companystruction of the sanads that the inams were grants of the villages with exemption from land revenue, because the words of the grant companyveyed the soil and rights over trees, water, mines etc.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Construction of sanads conveys soil and rights over trees, water, mines; distinction preserved in s.2(1)(e); High Court view correct.

anchor.surface_text: This view is obviously companyrect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmation of High Court's sanad construction as grants of villages exempt from revenue.

holdings.text: The nature of the assessment payable was not however altered thereby nor did it become land revenue.

anchor.surface_text: No Doubt since the introduction of the survey the amounts payable by the tenants to the inamdars were all assessed under the Code. The nature of the assessment payable was number however altered thereby number did it become land revenue.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Survey fixed amounts but did not change right to assessment; inamdar remained grantee of soil exempt from revenue; tenant liable for rent.

holdings.text: The distinction between the two kinds of grants... has been maintained by the Act by specifying in s. 2(1)(e) that an inam means a grant of a village with exemption from liability to pay land revenue and also a grant of land revenue only.

anchor.surface_text: Furthermore, the distinction between the two kinds of grants, is well recognised and has been maintained by the Act by specifying in s. 2 1 e that an inam means a grant of a village with exemption from liability to pay land revenue and also a grant of land revenue only.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory classification in s.2(1)(e) preserves recognized distinction between village grants and revenue grants.

holdings.text: The substance of the matter is that the inamdar has been deprived of his right to the assessment because the land has been made subject to payment of land revenue. His claim... is therefore in reality based on the ground that the lands which were free from revenue have been made subject to it.

anchor.surface_text: The inamdars right to appropriate to himself the assessment fixed by the survey and collected from the inferior holders existed only because he was exempt from the liability to pay land revenue.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Loss occasioned by s.5 subjecting lands to revenue; inferior holders pay govt directly; claim falls within s.17(5) bar despite not direct liability.

holdings.text: No compensation can therefore be assessed or awarded for the loss of these rights.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector asked the appellants to produce evidence in support of their claims under this head. They failed to do so. They could not even cite one instance of the exercise of any such right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence produced of exercise of forfeiture or reversion rights; impossible to value loss without material.

holdings.text: The loss resulting to the Inamdar is the direct consequence of the operation of these provisions [s.5(1),(2)(b)].

anchor.surface_text: No liability is, however, cast upon them to pay to the Government land revenue in respect of lands in the possession of inferior holders. This follows clearly from s. 5 of the Act and is not disputed by either set of parties to the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.5(1) creates liability to full assessment; s.5(2)(b) makes inferior holders primarily liable to govt.

holdings.text: The grants were grants of villages with partial exemption from payment of the land revenue and were personal inams of the first category specified in s.2(1)(e)(i).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held-and, in my opinion, rightly that the grants of the villages, on their true construction were grants of the soil. The inamdars were not required to pay any land revenue except the quit rent and some small haqs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: True construction of grants as soil with partial exemption; quit rent only.

holdings.text: The survey and settlement... made no difference in the character of the inams.

anchor.surface_text: The survey and settlement of the villages under s. 216 of the Land- Revenue Code, 1879 made nodifference in the character of the inams. The introduction of the survey settlement did not confer on the inferior holders the status, of occupants,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Continued as inferior holders under inamdar paying assessments to him; villages remained alienated.

holdings.text: The loss consequential on the abolition of the right to recover assessment is, therefore, nil... Such a claim is barred by s.17(5).

anchor.surface_text: Had the appellants right to recover assessment from the inferior holders not been abolished, they would have been entitled to recover the amounts. of assessments from the inferior holders and at the same time would have been liable to pay the identical amounts to the Government

holdings.reasoning_summary: Would recover and pay identical amounts to govt; claim grounded on subjection to full assessment barred by s.17(5).

holdings.text: The appellants could not establish any loss under this head.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the claim for compensation under the second head, the High Court rightly held that the appellants could not establish any loss under this head. They failed to show that they exercised any right of forfeiture or claimed any right of reversion at any time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Failed to show exercise of forfeiture or reversion rights.

holdings.text: A grant of a village or land with total or partial exemption from payment of land revenue is essentially different from a grant of land revenue, and the distinction has been preserved by the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants submit that in view of the ephemeral nature of their rights of reversion and forfeiture in respect of the lands held by the inferior holders, the grants of villages, as far as they relate to those lands, are assimilated to grants of land revenue

holdings.reasoning_summary: Essentially different; Act preserves distinction; inamdar retains various rights/benefits post-abolition.
